com.urbancode.ubuild.scripting.wrappers
Class JobTraceWrapper

java.lang.Object
  com.urbancode.ubuild.scripting.wrappers.WrapperBase
      com.urbancode.ubuild.scripting.wrappers.JobTraceWrapper

public class JobTraceWrapper
extends WrapperBase

Scripting class to give limited access to JobTrace information. This is exposed as 'trace' in some scripts.

Examples:

To get the name of the job trace: 

    trace.getName()
To get the id of the job trace: 
    trace.getId()
To get the status of the job trace: 
    trace.getStatus()
To check if the job trace has one of the success statuses: 
    trace.statusIsSuccess()
To check if the job trace has one of the failure statuses: 
    trace.statusIsFailure()
To get the name of the agent that the job trace ran on: 
    trace.getAgent()
To get the start date of the job trace: 
    trace.getStartDate()
To get the end date of the job trace: 
    trace.getEndDate()
To get the formatted duration of the job trace: 
    trace.getDuration()
To get the project for the job trace: 
    trace.getProject()
To get the mapping of steps to their statuses for the job trace: 
    trace.getStepList()
To get a link to the job trace: 
    trace.getUrl()
If you are using velocity scripts for Notification Templates, you don't have to use the full method name for getters: 
    trace.Name
    trace.Id
    trace.StartDate
    trace.EndDate
    trace.Duration
    trace.Project
    trace.StepList
    trace.Url
To display all job properties in a notification: 
    Job Properties:
    #set($jobProperties = $trace.properties)
    #foreach($propName in $jobProperties.keySet())
        $propName: $jobProperties.get($propName)
    #end
If you are trying to retrieve some job properties in a process, you would prefix the property with 'job/' For example, to get the status for a job: 
    ${p:job/status}
To check if the status of a job is a success status: 
    ${p:job/statusIsSuccess}
To get information like the project name from a job, you might need to chain some of these calls together. First, you would have to get the project and then get the name. For example: 
    ${p:job/project/name}
To get a specific property name 'specific.property' on the job: 
    ${p:job/properties[@name='specific.property'}

getDuration

public java.lang.String getDuration()
Get the duration of the job execution as a string in format days/hours/minutes/seconds. Eg. 1 d 11 h 14 m 32 s. If the job is not complete, the duration will continue to increase.
